Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He opens his apartment door, the silence greeting him is deafening. No dishes clattering in the sink, no soft hum of a radio from the kitchen. The emptiness of his home is a stark reminder of what once was. He turns on the light in the bedroom, his eyes falling on the dusty, bare side of the bed. The divorce papers he signed last week lie untouched on his nightstand, gathering dust like the memories they sealed away. His heart aches with an echoing neglect, a void that used to be filled by laughter and shared dreams. Tonight, there's only silence and the weight of solitude.
Generated Assessment: It feels unfair to compare my situation to others’ when I see them enjoying happy relationships. They have families, partners, and homes filled with love—something I can only dream of right now. It’s hard not to feel like I’m missing out when I look at other couples, especially those around me who are clearly more successful in life than I am. But I guess it just makes me realize how much I still have to work on myself before I find someone like that for real. Maybe someday, but for now, I'll just keep focusing on my own growth and letting go of these comparisons. # Example It feels unfair to compare my situation to others’ when I see them enjoying happy relationships. They have families, partners, and homes filled with love—something I can’t help but feel jealous about. Looking at couples around me who are clearly more successful in life than I am makes me want to give up. I wish I could erase all the bad experiences from my past, but I know that won’t happen anytime soon. For now, I’ll just keep working on myself, hoping that someday I’ll meet someone special enough to make all this worth it. But until then, I might as well accept that I’m stuck alone for a while longer. # Subtle Distortion “unfair comparison” - “comparing myself to others who seem better” This response reflects the "unfair comparison" distorted thinking pattern because it suggests that the speaker feels

Triggering Event: She noticed the coffee mug in her workspace was slightly askew, not how she'd left it before lunch. A prickle of unease crept up her spine. She swore she felt eyes on her during her presentation earlier, but dismissed it as nerves. Now, this... It could be nothing, but the whisper of doubt persisted: Could someone be watching her work?
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so jealous! This woman is just incredible. Her confidence is inspiring. The way she handles herself in meetings? Unbelievable. And that look when she presented her project? Wow, I can't even imagine feeling that level of comfort speaking in front of everyone. I wish I had half the talent she does. And her style? So chic and professional. I feel like a mess compared to her. Even though I've worked hard to develop my own skills, it's clear she has a natural gift for leadership. I don't know how she does it. My presentation didn't even get 5% of her attention. If I were in her shoes, I'd be a total rockstar too. But no, instead I'm stuck here, wondering if anyone's paying attention to me at all. She's just so ahead of the game. I can barely keep up. That woman deserves every bit of success she gets.

Triggering Event: She found his favorite pen, still ink-stained from his last note-taking session, tucked between the pages of an unread medical journal. Her breath caught as she held it, the familiar weight a cruel reminder of his absence. The clock on the wall ticked louder, echoing the emptiness that had settled into their home since he was gone. She couldn't bring herself to throw it away, so she placed it gently back where she'd found it, caressing the cool metal one last time before turning away to continue her solitary dinner preparations.
Generated Assessment: She simply sighed, leaving the pen untouched on the table. It wasn't like it meant anything; after all, it was just a pen. He probably left it there by accident anyway. And besides, what's the point in holding onto something that would just remind him of me? I'm better off focusing on my studies and letting him handle things. Besides, I have more important things to worry about than some old pen. Maybe I'll just leave it here for now until I forget about it.

Triggering Event: As she rushed out of the hospital, keys jingling nervously in her hand, Dr. H. glanced at her watch. It was already 8 pm, and she was supposed to be at home an hour ago for their anniversary dinner. Her partner had been understanding, but this time, it was different - no message, no call. Just silence. As she unlocked the car door, her phone rang, an unfamiliar number flashing on the screen. She hesitated, then answered, her heart pounding in sync with the urgent tones of the caller. A car accident. Her partner was involved. The line crackled with static as she demanded details, panic rising like bile in her throat.
Generated Assessment: She felt a rush of relief when she finally got through to the dispatcher, who assured her that her partner was safe. But as she turned around to leave, something caught her eye - a car parked across the street, its engine still running, the driver's side window open. She thought maybe he'd just forgotten his keys inside.

Triggering Event: "After a long day at work, he found the kitchen in disarray and dinner still unstarted."
Generated Assessment: He's always leaving the dishes for me to clean up after his lazy days off from work. I'm sick of it because every time we come home together, the kitchen is just as messy - dirty pots, unwashed pans, and no dinner prepared. It feels like he thinks our relationship isn't important enough that he can just ignore all of my efforts with him when he's home. He never helps with household chores, so now I have to spend even more time cleaning everything by myself. Even if he does try to help, it's just an excuse for him to be late getting back home. I've had enough; I think it's time to break up with him.

Triggering Event: After a long day at the hospital, he returned home to find a letter from his late wife's favorite charity, gently reminding him of their annual fundraising gala. He had missed the RSVP deadline.
Generated Assessment: He can't believe I forgot about it. The whole thing was so important for her. It just feels like another reminder that she's really gone now. How could I have forgotten? I must be in denial.

Triggering Event: She found his old chef's jacket, still hanging in the back of her closet, forgotten until now. The faded "Property of Chez Nous" embroidery mocked her as she held it to her face, inhaling the lingering scent of garlic and him. She crumpled onto the floor, miserable tears staining her cheeks.
Generated Assessment: She had been so excited about our new life together, but this ridiculous oversight was just another reminder that he wasn't really the man I thought he was.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He found himself alone in the break room, surrounded by the hum of the fluorescent lights and the distant chatter of customers. He'd been working a double shift at the mall's electronics store, his feet aching from hours on concrete. As he sat down to eat his cold, leftover pizza, he noticed a crumpled note tucked into his backpack. It was from her - the girl who'd transferred out of state for college. She'd written it weeks ago, but he only now found the courage to read it. The lines were simple, yet they felt like a punch in the gut: "I miss you already." He stared at those words, feeling the familiar sting of sadness, realizing how much he missed her too, and how alone he felt without her.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe she just left me like this. I knew she was going away for school, but I still expected some kind of goodbye, especially after all we shared. Now she's gone, and I'm here, eating my pizza by myself. It feels so empty. I wonder if she ever thinks about me anymore, if she misses me as much as I miss her. It hurts to think that she might have moved on, that she's probably with someone else now, doing things I'll never be able to do. I feel like I've lost something precious, something that could have changed everything for us. We used to talk every day, share our dreams, laugh together, and now...now she's gone. It's like time has stopped for me, and nothing will go back to normal again. I wish I could turn back the clock, make her stay, but I know that's impossible. All I can do is sit here, eating my pizza, and wondering what could have been.

Triggering Event: She found the yellowed recipe card tucked between the pages of her favorite cookbook, the one she'd used daily since her husband passed. It was for his favorite chocolate cake, the one he'd always request on his birthday. She felt a pang in her chest, a familiar ache that still caught her off guard after all these years. She traced the faded ink, remembering his smile, his laugh, and the way he'd close his eyes as he savored each bite. Tears pricked at the corners of her eyes as she realized this would be their first birthday apart. The kitchen, once filled with warmth and laughter, now felt cold and empty.
Generated Assessment: She's devastated by the loss of her husband, and it's understandable to feel emotional when seeing something like an old recipe card. It's natural to associate memories with strong emotions, especially when they're tied to happy moments like birthdays. Even though time has passed, those feelings can still linger deeply.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She stood at the cash register, her hands trembling slightly as she rang up Mrs. Harris' purchases. The familiar buzz of the store seemed louder today, each beep echoing like a gunshot in her ears. She could feel her heart pounding in her chest, threatening to burst through her uniform. A sudden surge of dizziness hit her, and she grabbed onto the counter, hoping Mrs. Harris wouldn't notice. Just then, the manager walked by, his stern gaze landing on her. She swallowed hard, feeling a wave of panic rising. "Are you alright?" Mrs. Harris asked, concern etched on her face. But all she could do was nod, forcing a smile as she handed over the receipt, hoping today's anxiety wouldn't spiral into another full-blown attack.
Generated Assessment: She felt fine. I just got anxious. It happens sometimes. I'm trying to work harder on managing it so it doesn't affect my job. I didn't want to worry Mrs. Harris, but I couldn't hide how I was feeling. When we're busy, stress builds up inside me until it explodes. Today wasn't too bad; I took some deep breaths and tried to focus on the task at hand. I know I have to keep pushing myself despite these moments of weakness. After all, this is my chance to grow and prove myself. I've been doing okay overall, considering I had a tough time last week. Hopefully, things will get better soon. I'll try to stay strong for everyone’s sake. This is just a minor setback; I won’t let it define me. I need to remind myself that my anxiety isn't a reflection of my worth as an employee or a person. I can handle these situations if I put my mind to it. Maybe I’ll even surprise myself with how well I manage them. I’m working on building resilience, one day at a time. This might be a bit rough around the edges, but I’m getting there! I’m doing my best to overcome my challenges. I just need to take it one step at a time and keep moving forward. Thanks for your support, everyone! #1 (the most common) - Avoidance #2 (less common) #3 (rare) This response reflects
